episode_title: Silicon Valley to Silicone Manufacturing: An AI-Powered Evolution with Dan Thompson
transcript:
ï»¿Dant (00:00.078)
So if I wanted to, when I go to share my desktop, I'm just looking at how to do it in this.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:00.172)
 up.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:05.249)
So there's the share button.


Dant (00:07.512)
Got it. Perfect. Got it.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:08.843)
and then that will allow you to share. So Dan, I'm really excited. I was at the gym this morning with my kids and I just sent out this tweet which was, hey, is anybody actually utilizing AI? And if you are, I just want to know about it. And you were one of the people that responded to it. And you're like, hey, I'm grinding. It's Saturday. I'm at the office. I'm willing to show you. So I'm just excited to be having the conversation with you. Where are you?


Dant (00:33.646)
So Nick, I'm in Weatherford, Texas, which is right next to Fort Worth. And we are family-owned silicone company where we compound materials and then we manufacture products for our customers who could be in appliance, auto, many different industries. So you never see our brand publicly, but if the product requires silicone for the durability and reliability of that environment, that's what we make.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:00.919)
Okay, so you're not the silicone casting, you're not the mold, essentially, that they're using to make the products. You're the silicone that's actually in the product.


Dant (01:08.546)
Yeah, we compound the silicone and then we have extrusion and molding where we actually make the products. We've been doing it for 50 years. Traditionally, we were autos where we got our start and now we are in many different industries. So it's a very exciting time for us.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:17.943)
Wow.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:27.731)
my god, did you start the business?


Dant (01:30.188)
No, a friend of mine, his name is Alan McAleff, started the business. He would be like our father's age and as he was looking for how the business would operate for the next generation, I...


had been at Microsoft for 20 years and retired and I said, hey, I want to run it for you. And I've subsequently brought his daughter into the business and his son runs some couple other businesses they have and we're having a blast. I was happy to step out of high tech Fortune five company and move into family owned business world.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:05.559)
That's a really, I think that's a really cool contrast, especially given now with AI, think. It's becoming starker even.


Dant (02:11.202)
Yeah, it's really...


It's really funny, there's a lot of manufacturing people like us who are just these incredible family-owned businesses and they get the worst technology. They're not big enough to get Fortune 500 kind of technology. And so you have to be scrappy and I've seen AI as an equalizer. Of course, I come from a strong technology background, but I was a very poor developer and I thought, how are we going to leverage AI in our business to give us


the benefits that many of the larger companies have. And we're doing that in a couple areas. So five years ago.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:50.261)
When did you buy or when did you step into the business? Five years ago, okay. And for you, can you give me an idea like number of employees or top line revenue?


Dant (03:00.078)
Yeah, we've got about 225 employees. We shipped almost 70 million units of stuff.


and units could be pounds or packages or whatnot. And some of those units are about the size of a tic tac. So don't let the big number blow you away. But we're a pretty serious manufacturing company in our county here west of Fort Worth. We're the second largest private employer in the county, number two user of electricity. So there's a lot of responsibilities that go into how we work with the county.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:15.191)
Sure.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:36.129)
This is why I love social media. You and I would have never met. You would have never met. I sent some random tweet, and here we are in the middle of a Saturday. I'm stupid, so help me understand. You're manufacturing the silicone? Do you take the raw material and then put it in? OK.


Dant (03:38.092)
I know, it's so cool.


Dant (03:52.142)
Correct. So most of the world, and you think of this as a plastic water bottle. Plastics are hydrocarbon based and they serve most of our consumable needs for materials like plastics. From like high end that may come in the form of a speaker or something like that to just cheap plastic stuff.


Silicone uses instead of carbon, a silicone backbone. And if you look on a periodic chart, you've got carbon right under it is silicone. So in many ways they're very similar, carbon being the backbone of life, silicone being what's often the science fiction backbone of life.


Silicone has different properties than carbon and allows us to build materials that work at much lower and much higher temperatures. Silicone also allows us to make it a material which insulates, like in the case of a spark plug boot, where the spark plug goes down into the boot. You can't have an electrical surface related to that. And we can also reverse the conductivity of silicone by the way that we treat it. So it's a very versatile material.


very sustainable because it's not using hydrocarbons and if we mold something and came back 5,000 years from now it will still be exactly like it was. It doesn't have the problems with UV light. So when you build things in it's always a more expensive option but if it's something that has the material characteristics that need to perform at those levels it's the pathway to go.


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:21.601)
Wow.


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:35.159)
Okay, so I'm again, I'm a Neanderthal. I'm gonna try my best to restate to you. I'm gonna be using words. just have no idea if I'm using them right. So if you have a product, whatever it is, and there's something that you would need plastic typically for.


Dant (05:38.936)
Not at all. Not at all. Yeah.


Jack, you're doing great.


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:54.973)
Silicon is the much better application if there are very high or very low temperatures and or if there are applications that require connectivity or conductivity. So it can also function as a conductor. I don't know if I even said those words right, but like plastic is kind of the cheaper version in more applications. Silicon is the higher version.


Dant (06:00.696)
Yes.


Dant (06:07.084)
Yep.


Dant (06:17.292)
Yeah, silicone is a little more expensive version, and it's really built for things that need durability or have certain temperature constraints. I'll give you a couple examples that just fly through some. So we talked about spark plug boots. If you drove a car from the 70s, 80s, 90s, 2000s in the United States that was manufactured here, your spark plug boots came from this factory. So that's like an example of our scale.


Nikolas Hulewsky (06:31.489)
Spark plugs.


Nikolas Hulewsky (06:42.485)
Really?


Dant (06:47.134)
If you looked at an F-14, 15, F-35, F-22 fighter jet, when the canopy seal closes, there is a silicon seal that we build that supports the pilot's life by properly pressurizing and maintaining its characteristics in those environments. If you look at construction, you have to have fire seals around certain doors in construction.


rebuild the fire seals that go with those. Low temperatures, Thermo Fisher is the number one low temperature freezer for medical industry. was very big in pandemic. Yeah, Thermo Fisher, they were the, where vaccines were held at a certain low temperature, the gaskets that went on those doors came out of this factory.

Primo Fisher, that's a company,

We build certain things that go in there that are used in mining and blueprint applications. the really great example to just crystallize it, a lot of us remember when the space shuttle blew up when we were kids.


And that was a failure of an O-ring on that rocket. And all the engineers told NASA before it launched that it was going to be an issue because it wasn't made out of silicone. And that was the material failure that caused it to explode that day. So that's what we mean by when situation really counts, we're the critical material that should be used.


Nikolas Hulewsky (08:32.129)
I love that, I don't know if you just thought of that on the fly, but that tagline, when the situation really counts, where the material you use, that's fantastic.

I think it's for a living.

I love this. think you're the perfect comp- I'm so excited that I'm talking to you. This might be the best conversation I ever have around this because you fit the perfect profile. You're, you're an old school company in the sense that you're doing manufacturing, right? But you know, are there AI use cases that can make you more efficient? Before I get to the AI, what I do want to ask though is, silicon's not heavy, is it?

Yeah.


Dant (09:05.858)
That's right.


Dant (09:12.387)
sure.

It's like plastics. can be both soft or it can be hard.

So my question with that would be, why do we manufacture it domestically? Why not have it manufactured in China or Indonesia or Vietnam and then have it shipped over? Does that make sense?


Dant (09:33.742)
So, yeah, no, so actually in our company, you know, I've talked about primarily the manufacturing facility we have here. We also have co-owned or now have partnerships in Vietnam and China with manufacturers over there. The reason that it's important, part of the reason that we've survived 50 years is that we've been able to serve our customers whether they needed an offshore part or a domestic part.


Nikolas Hulewsky (09:48.33)
Okay.


Dant (10:01.262)
And the real future of our company is the domestic growth, but there's times where customers want to hedge their bet and use that lower cost source part. And so we provide the flexibility to do both of those. But really, it's an absolute nightmare.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:13.921)
How do you view the tariffs? Do tariffs affect you at all? Is it?


Dant (10:20.95)
One of the things when people talk about tariffs, they don't understand how complex the transaction is, once it's received to us. CH Robinson is the shipping and forwarder, and they're an absolute state-of-the-art company that processes them, because you don't know the tariff until you actually clear import. So as the tariffs are discussed, and there's volatility and policy, you don't know what tariff will be assessed when it comes through.


We're certainly in favor of the tariffs and the chaos because it creates opportunity for us. It's bringing things domestically.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:57.109)
Yeah.


Dant (10:59.128)
But the internal management of it is an absolute nightmare. We are looking at a piece of AI there to pull out based on the, you get a PDF document that has your shipping manifest and it has the tariff charges. And so when we went through this four years ago, it was difficult. This time we will probably have it scanned and run through a piece of AI to produce a structured output showing us what those tariffs are so that we can run it into our systems.


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:28.375)
That's one of the crazy things. I did not know this and you will probably correct me because you know this better than I do. But I didn't know there's two types of PDFs. There's a HTML PDF, which is effectively mapped. Every character that you see on that PDF is mapped. So it's very easy for software to be built around that type of PDF. But then there's like 25 % of PDFs that are just pictures. It could be a picture with your phone. It could be a scan.


whatever you want to call it, or there's handwriting on it. And that is hard to build software around. But from what I understand, where AI comes in. So correct me.


Dant (11:59.63)
You're probably right. I talked about PDFs a little differently just as being simple and messy.


Nikolas Hulewsky (12:11.04)
Yeah.

You know, in a simple one, you can decompose the text that's in it really easy. And in a messy one, it's just a lot more complicated. And then you're going to train it to say, hey, if you're...


wanting tariff information, these are the numbers that we want off that page. And you don't have to code like you used to with all these details. You're literally, it reads it, it understands it, and you're telling it what fields you want pulled out of it. So a lot of those arguments that used to be problems are no longer problems.

Well, like I said, you are at this very interesting intersection, 20 years at Microsoft. What did you do at Microsoft?

So I really understand the business customer. I don't have any experience on the Xbox side or some of those on their sides. It's kind of always behind the scenes, but we,

That's perfect for what you're doing.

We did projects like when Apple wanted to build the iCloud. It's branded for Apple, but at that time it was shared across Amazon and Microsoft, and so we helped them build it. Things like that.

That's awesome. All right, and then obviously you have the manufacturing experience. How are you using AI in your business right now?

Yeah, you know, maybe we could tip dip our toe into a couple things and.

Okay.

And by setting those instructions, you can get very different outcomes because you send your questions to a large language model. It has context about how you want it thought about.

Sure.

and then it returns it.

So when customers come to us and they think, you know, hey, I'm doing this, could you do that?
